sen.j: 神世七代(かみのよななよ)とは、日本神話で、天地開闢 (日本神話)のとき生成した七代の神の総称。
sen.e: Kaminoyonanayo is a general term for seven generations of deities who were born when heaven and earth were created in Japanese Mythology.
Kaminoyonanayo is a general term for seven generations of deities who were born when heaven and earth were created in Japanese Mythology.
Kaminoyonanayo is a general term for seven generations of deities who were born when heaven and earth were created in Japanese Mythology.

sen.j: またはその時代をいう。
sen.e: Or it refers to such an era.
Or it refers to such an era.
Or it refers to such an era.

sen.j: 神代七代とも書き、天神七代ともいう。
sen.e: It is also described as 神代七代 in Japanese and is also called Tenjin Shichidai.
It is also described as 神代七代 in Japanese and is also called Tenjin Shichidai.
It is also described as 神代七代 in Japanese and is also called Tenjin Shichidai.

sen.j: 初めは、抽象的だった神々が、次第に男女に別れ、異性を感じるようになり、最終的には愛を見つけ出し夫婦となる過程をもって、男女の体や性が整っていくことを表す部分だと言われている。
sen.e: The way abstract deities are gradually divided into a man and a woman, become aware of the opposite sex and eventually find love which leads to marriage is said to imply how the bodies and sexes of a man and a woman are properly differentiated.

The way abstract deities are gradually divided into a man and a woman, become aware of the opposite sex and eventually find love which leads to marriage is said to imply how the bodies and sexes of a man and a woman are properly differentiated.

The way abstract deities are gradually divided into a man and a woman, become aware of the opposite sex and eventually find love which leads to marriage is said to imply how the bodies and sexes of a man and a woman are properly differentiated.

sen.j: 古事記
sen.e: Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters)
Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters)
Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters)

sen.j: 古事記では、別天津神の次に現れた十二柱七代の神を神世七代としている。
sen.e: In Kojiki, Kaminoyonanayo are Junihashira nanayo no kami (Twelve deities of seven generations) who appeared after Kotoamatsukami (Literally, Separate heavenly kami).
In Kojiki, Kaminoyonanayo are Junihashira nanayo no kami (Twelve deities of seven generations) who appeared after Kotoamatsukami (Literally, Separate heavenly kami).
In Kojiki, Kaminoyonanayo are Junihashira nanayo no kami (Twelve deities of seven generations) who appeared after Kotoamatsukami (Literally, Separate heavenly kami).

sen.j: 最初の二代は一柱で一代、その後は二柱で一代と数えて七代とする。
sen.e: There is one deity in each of the first two generations, and there are two deities in each of the third or later generations, and so the total number of generations becomes seven.
There is one deity in each of the first two generations, and there are two deities in each of the third or later generations, and so the total number of generations becomes seven.
There is one deity in each of the first two generations, and there are two deities in each of the third or later generations, and so the total number of generations becomes seven.

sen.j: （左側が男神、右側が女神）

sen.j: 日本書紀
sen.e: Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)
Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)

sen.j: 日本書紀の本書では、天地開闢の最初に現れた以下の十一柱七代の神を神世七代としている。
sen.e: In Nihonshoki, Kaminoyonanayo are Juichihashira nanayo no kami (Eleven deities of seven generations) who appeared at the beginning of creation of heaven and earth:

tit.e: List of the Appearances of the Deities

sen.j: ・は別神であるが便宜上同一代に記載
sen.e: A deity whose name is marked with a dot (•) is different from the other deity or deities in the same generation group, but they are conveniently categorized into the same group.
sen.cmt: ネットで調べたところ、文頭に「・」がついていたので、付け加えました。
